titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Madeline Earle Stanton Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Bella Z. Berson

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers include correspondence, diaries, writings, memorabilia, and photographs documenting Madeline Stanton's bibliographic and administrative support of the work of Harvey Cushing and John Fulton, as well as her personal affairs.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Yale University Medical Historical Library, 1988; and gift of Ruth Judge, 1992 and 1994.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Madeline Earle Stanton Papers (MS 1482). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in four series: Series I. Correspondence, 1921-1983. Series II. Personal Papers, 1916-1981. Series III. Projects, 1922-1971. Series IV. Audiovisual Materials, 1927-1962.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Madeline Earle Stanton was born on June 9, 1898, in Canton, Massachusetts. After receiving her B.A. degree from Smith College in 1919, she was secretary to Agide Jacchia, conductor of the Boston Pops Orchestra. Beginning in 1920, Stanton worked with Dr. Harvey Cushing at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston and later at the Yale School of Medicine. After Cushing's death in 1939, Stanton collaborated with Yale Professor John Fulton on bibliographic works on Michael Servetus and Robert Boyle. She was appointed secretary of the Yale Medical Historical Library in 1941. In 1949, her title changed to librarian of the Yale Medical Historical Collections. From 1951-1961, she was also research assistant in bibliography in the Yale Department of the History of Medicine. She was an assistant editor of the Journal of the History of Medicine and Allied Science from 1961-1972. Stanton died in Hamden, Connecticut on October 25, 1980.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers include correspondence, diaries, writings, memorabilia, and photographs documenting Madeline Stanton's bibliographic and administrative support of the work of Harvey Cushing and John Fulton, as well as her personal affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes Madeline Stanton's correspondence with her family, John Fulton, his family and students, and professional colleagues. The files are arranged alphabetically by personal and corporate name. The papers suggest the mixture of the professional with the personal in Stanton's life. The correspondence documents bibliographic and publication questions and administrative issues associated with the Yale Medical Historical Library.

About twenty percent of the correspondence is from John Fulton. In his letters, Fulton describes many of the same conferences, trips, and other events which he recorded in his diaries. In treating Stanton as a confidante, Fulton expresses a more personal view of these events. The diaries, volumes of which are held in the Medical Historical Library, were widely shared with friends and relatives and, therefore, more circumspect.

Other correspondents include Charles D. O'Malley, an authority on the work of Vesalius, associates from Harvey Cushing's group at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital including William R. Henderson, Hugh Cairns and Julia Shepley, and associates of John Fulton including Oliver Hayward and William W. Francis. Some correspondents, Francis for example, addressed letters to Stanton and Elizabeth Thomson jointly. The correspondence is closely associated with similar files in the papers of John Fulton (MS 1236) and Elizabeth Thomson (MS 1623). Business letters that Stanton wrote on behalf of Fulton are filed, for the most part, with the Fulton Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is arranged by type of material. Of particular note are Stanton's handwritten diaries which contain personal reflections on family affairs and daily events in Cushing's unit at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital and at Yale University from 1928-1939. In them, she records her observations on colleagues, doctors, and cases. The diary typescripts from 1948 and 1951 describe her trips abroad. This series includes files on Madeline Stanton's estate, genealogy and memorabilia. Biographical information is available in a copy of a library school thesis on Madeline Stanton, which also includes a bibliography of her writings.

did.unittitle: "M. E. Stanton and the Historical Library of the Yale Medical Library" [thesis by Joelle R. Blankfort]
Estate [includes will; birth and death certificates]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes several files related to Stanton's writings about Cushing and the Yale Medical Historical Library. Additional files document projects relating to Stanton's association with Harvey Cushing. They include her notebook indexing Cushing's office files and her efforts to respond to requests for copies of the sculpture made of Cushing's hands. Correspondence concerning Stanton's work on the publication of the second edition of John Fulton's Selected Readings in the History of Physiology , particularly the illustrations used in the edition, is included.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Correspondence re efforts to reproduce the original sculpture.

did.unittitle: Selected Readings in the History of Physiology , 2nd ed. [illustrations, correspondence]
"The Working Day of an Historical Library" [correspondence, draft]
"The Medical Historical Library on the Hundredth Birthday of Harvey Cushing"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes Soundscriber discs and photographs of Stanton. The Soundscriber discs include John Fulton's dictation responding to routine correspondence and Paul MacLean responding to Stanton's request for assistance in answering correspondence after Fulton's death. Of particular interest is the disc of Robert Livingston's discussion of Fulton's scientific work. This was made in response to Stanton's request for assistance in preparing an exhibition at the Yale Medical Library to honor Fulton after his death. Livingston had worked with Fulton in the Yale Laboratory of Physiology. Researchers must listen to the discs on equipment available in the Yale Historical Sound Recordings Room.
